segment.source: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM
segment.target: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM

segment.source: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM
segment.target: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM

segment.source: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM
segment.target: Enable or Disable Windows Features Using DISM

segment.source: The Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool is a command-line tool that is used to modify Windows® images.
segment.target: The Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool is a command-line tool that is used to modify Windows® images.

segment.source: You can use DISM to enable or disable Windows features directly from the command prompt, or by applying an answer file to the image.
segment.target: You can use DISM to enable or disable Windows features directly from the command prompt, or by applying an answer file to the image.

segment.source: You can enable or disable Windows features offline on a WIM or VHD file, or online on a running operating system.
segment.target: You can enable or disable Windows features offline on a WIM or VHD file, or online on a running operating system.

segment.source: To mount an offline image for servicing
segment.target: To mount an offline image for servicing

segment.source: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.
segment.target: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.

segment.source: To use DISM from an installation of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), locate the Windows ADK servicing folder and navigate to this directory.
segment.target: To use DISM from an installation of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), locate the Windows ADK servicing folder and navigate to this directory.

segment.source: By default, DISM is installed at C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10.0Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 10, C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits8.1Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 8.1and C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits8.0Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 8.
segment.target: By default, DISM is installed at C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10.0Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 10, C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits8.1Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 8.1and C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits8.0Assessment and Deployment KitDeployment Tools in Windows 8.

segment.source: DISM is available in:
segment.target: DISM is available in:

segment.target: Windows 10

segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 8
segment.target: Windows 8

segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

segment.source: Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Server 2012

segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) for Windows 10

segment.source: WinPE 5.0
segment.target: WinPE 5.0

segment.source: WinPE 4.0
segment.target: WinPE 4.0

segment.source: You can install DISM and other deployment and imaging tools, such as Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), on another supported operating system from the Windows ADK.
segment.target: You can install DISM and other deployment and imaging tools, such as Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), on another supported operating system from the Windows ADK.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM Supported Platforms.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM Supported Platforms.

segment.source: Use the option to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.
segment.target: Use the option to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to modify.

segment.source: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.
segment.target: An index or name value is required for most operations that specify an image file.

segment.source: You can use to redirect the output of the command to a text file that is named featurelist.
segment.target: You can use to redirect the output of the command to a text file that is named featurelist.

segment.source: Review the list of features to find the feature that you want to enable, disable, remove, or restore.
segment.target: Review the list of features to find the feature that you want to enable, disable, remove, or restore.

segment.source: Use to list information about the specific feature you are interested in.
segment.target: Use to list information about the specific feature you are interested in.

segment.target: You can use the argument to enable all of the parent features in the same command.

segment.source: If the status is Enble Pending, you must boot the image in order to enable the feature entirely.
segment.target: If the status is Enble Pending, you must boot the image in order to enable the feature entirely.

segment.source: To restore removed Windows features
segment.target: To restore removed Windows features

segment.source: Enable a specific feature in the image.
segment.target: Enable a specific feature in the image.

segment.source: If you do not specify a source, DISM will look in the default location specified by group policy for the required files needed to enable the feature For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.
segment.target: If you do not specify a source, DISM will look in the default location specified by group policy for the required files needed to enable the feature For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.

segment.source: If the files are not found in the default location, DISM will contact Windows Update (WU) for the required files.
segment.target: If the files are not found in the default location, DISM will contact Windows Update (WU) for the required files.

segment.source: You can use the argument to prevent DISM from contacting WU.
segment.target: You can use the argument to prevent DISM from contacting WU.

segment.source: If you specify multiple arguments, the files are gathered from the first location where they are found and the rest of the locations are ignored.
segment.target: If you specify multiple arguments, the files are gathered from the first location where they are found and the rest of the locations are ignored.

segment.source: If the status is EnablePending, you must boot the image in order to enable the feature entirely.
segment.target: If the status is EnablePending, you must boot the image in order to enable the feature entirely.

segment.target: This option can only be used when servicing Windows 10, Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview, Windows Server 2012 R2, or Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: The status is Disabled.
segment.target: The status is Disabled.

segment.source: Beginning with Windows 10, the payload is not removed from Windows client SKUs in order to support push-button reset.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows 10, the payload is not removed from Windows client SKUs in order to support push-button reset.

segment.source: The payload is removed from Windows Server SKUs.
segment.target: The payload is removed from Windows Server SKUs.

segment.source: To enable or disable Windows features by using DISM and an answer file
segment.target: To enable or disable Windows features by using DISM and an answer file

segment.source: In Windows SIM, open an existing catalog by clicking Select a Windows Image on the File menu and specifying the catalog file type (.clg) in the drop-down list, or create a new catalog by clicking Create Catalog on the Tools menu.
segment.target: In Windows SIM, open an existing catalog by clicking Select a Windows Image on the File menu and specifying the catalog file type (.clg) in the drop-down list, or create a new catalog by clicking Create Catalog on the Tools menu.

segment.source: Expand the catalog in the Windows Image pane, and then expand Packages.
segment.target: Expand the catalog in the Windows Image pane, and then expand Packages.

segment.source: Expand Foundation, and right-click Microsoft-Windows-Foundation-Package.
segment.target: Expand Foundation, and right-click Microsoft-Windows-Foundation-Package.

segment.source: Click Add to Answer File.
segment.target: Click Add to Answer File.

segment.source: Click Enabled or Disabled next to the features that you intend to enable or disable.
segment.target: Click Enabled or Disabled next to the features that you intend to enable or disable.

segment.source: Click the arrow to select the opposite choice.
segment.target: Click the arrow to select the opposite choice.

segment.source: You might have to expand an item to see all its children.
segment.target: You might have to expand an item to see all its children.

segment.source: You must enable the parent if any one of its children are enabled.
segment.target: You must enable the parent if any one of its children are enabled.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can't restore or remove a Windows feature for features on demand with an unattended answer file.
segment.target: You can't restore or remove a Windows feature for features on demand with an unattended answer file.

segment.source: Click Tools on the main menu, and then click Validate Answer File.
segment.target: Click Tools on the main menu, and then click Validate Answer File.

segment.source: Correct any errors that appear in the Messages pane, and save the answer file.
segment.target: Correct any errors that appear in the Messages pane, and save the answer file.

segment.source: At the command prompt, type the following command to apply the unattended answer file to the image.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type the following command to apply the unattended answer file to the image.

segment.source: To service an offline image, specify the location of the mounted image directory.
segment.target: To service an offline image, specify the location of the mounted image directory.

segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the image.
